Comment: TLDR; In March 2025, the U.S. trade deficit surged to a record $140.5 billion, **nearly doubling from the previous year**. This spike was largely due to businesses and consumers accelerating imports ahead of President Trump's sweeping tariffs announced for April 2, dubbed “Liberation Day.” Imports rose to nearly $419 billion, with pharmaceutical products—primarily from Ireland—increasing by $20.9 billion, indicating significant pre-tariff stockpiling. The surge in imports contributed to a 0.3% contraction in U.S. GDP for the first quarter, marking the first decline in three years. Economists anticipate that this import surge is temporary and expect the trade deficit to decrease in the coming months as the effects of the tariffs take hold.
